content.text: The art and science of selecting and overseeing a mix of investments (stocks, bonds, ETFs, commodities, etc.) to achieve long-term financial goals.
Purpose: Balance growth potential with risk, ensuring your investments align with your risk tolerance, time horizon, and objectives.
Diversification: Spreading investments across different asset classes reduces the impact of any single investment’s poor performance.

content.title: Main Asset Classes
items: Stocks: Higher risk, higher potential return. Provide growth.
Bonds: Lower risk, steady income. Provide stability.
ETFs (Exchange-Traded Funds): Pooled investments that track indexes, sectors, or commodities; offer diversification at low cost.
Commodities (e.g., gold, oil): Can hedge against inflation or market downturns.

content.text: Risk: The chance that investments may lose value.
Reward: The potential returns you expect for taking on risk.

content.title: Key Measures
items: Volatility: How much investment prices fluctuate. High volatility = higher risk.
Beta: A measure of how much an investment moves compared to the market (e.g., beta > 1 means more volatile than the market).
Standard Deviation: A statistical measure of variability in returns; higher deviation means more uncertainty in performance.

content.text: When managing a portfolio, it’s not just about picking investments — it’s about understanding how risky they are. These three measures help investors compare and balance their choices.
The degree to which an investment’s price goes up and down over time.
High volatility can bring big gains but also steep losses. Low volatility means steadier performance.

content.title: Example
items: A tech stock may swing +10% one week and –8% the next, while a government bond may barely move. Which one you choose depends on your risk tolerance.

content.text: A measure of how much an investment moves compared to the overall market (usually compared to the S&P 500 or a broad index).
It tells you if an asset is more or less sensitive to market changes.

content.title: Example
items: Beta = 1: Moves about the same as the market.
Beta > 1: More volatile (e.g., a stock with beta 1.5 rises 15% when the market rises 10%).
Beta < 1: Less volatile (e.g., utilities with beta 0.5 rise only 5% when the market rises 10%).
Investor takeaway: Conservative investors often prefer lower-beta stocks, while aggressive investors may seek higher beta for greater upside.

content.text: A statistical measure of how spread out returns are from their average.
Higher standard deviation means more unpredictable performance.

content.title: Example
items: A mutual fund with a standard deviation of 20% might swing between –20% and +20% in a year.
Another fund with 10% swings less, offering more stability.
Investor takeaway: Compare funds or ETFs using standard deviation to understand which ones carry more risk.

content.text: The process of dividing your portfolio among different asset classes (stocks, bonds, cash, etc.) based on your personal situation.

content.title: Types of Allocation
items: Age-Based: Younger investors may invest more in stocks (growth), while older investors lean towards bonds (stability).
Risk-Based: Aggressive investors tilt towards stocks; conservative investors lean towards bonds and cash.
Goal-Based: Allocation depends on the purpose of investing (e.g., saving for retirement, buying a home, or funding education).
Management Fees: Paid to portfolio managers or advisors.
Fund Expense Ratios: Ongoing fees for mutual funds or ETFs.
Trading Costs: Commissions or bid-ask spreads when buying/selling.
Market Risk: Overall market declines can affect most assets.
Concentration Risk: Too much exposure to one sector or asset class increases vulnerability.
Interest Rate Risk: Rising rates can hurt bonds.
Inflation Risk: Reduces the purchasing power of investment returns.
A diversified portfolio balances risk and reward.
Asset allocation is the most important driver of long-term returns.
Risk tolerance, goals, and time horizon should guide portfolio decisions.
Monitoring and rebalancing are essential to keep your portfolio aligned with your strategy.
